title: Ezekiel Chapter 29 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 29 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 29 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 29.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 29:2, to whom did the word of the LORD command Ezekiel to prophesy against?
options: Pharaoh king of Egypt
King Nebuchadrezzar
King David
The people of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh king of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:2 states that the word of the LORD came to Ezekiel commanding him to prophesy against Pharaoh king of Egypt and all Egypt.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29:3, how is Pharaoh described?
options: A great dragon lying in the midst of his rivers
A lion prowling in the desert
A mighty eagle soaring above the land
A serpent in the garden
questions.correctAnswer: A great dragon lying in the midst of his rivers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:3 describes Pharaoh as the great dragon lying in the midst of his rivers.

questions.question: What did God say He would put in Pharaoh's jaws in Ezekiel 29:4?
options: Hooks
Chains
Fire
Water
questions.correctAnswer: Hooks
questions.explanation: In Ezekiel 29:4, God says He will put hooks in Pharaoh's jaws to pull him out of his rivers.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 29:5 says Pharaoh and the fish of his rivers shall be gathered together.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:5 states that Pharaoh and all the fish of his rivers shall fall upon the open fields and shall not be gathered together.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29:6, why will all the inhabitants of Egypt know that the LORD is God?
options: Because they were a staff of reed to the house of Israel
Because they built great pyramids
Because they worshipped the LORD
Because they defeated Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Because they were a staff of reed to the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:6 explains that Egypt will know the LORD because they were a staff of reed to the house of Israel.

questions.question: What did Egypt do to Israel when they took hold of them, according to Ezekiel 29:7?
options: Broke and rent their shoulder
Blessed and helped them
Led them to safety
Gave them gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Broke and rent their shoulder
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:7 states that when Israel took hold of Egypt by the hand, Egypt broke and rent their shoulder.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 29:8 says the LORD will bring peace upon Egypt.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:8 declares that the LORD will bring a sword upon Egypt and cut off man and beast, not peace.

questions.question: For how many years will the land of Egypt be desolate, according to Ezekiel 29:11?
options: Forty years
Ten years
Seventy years
One hundred years
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:11 states that Egypt shall be uninhabited for forty years.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Ezekiel 29:13: 'At the end of ______ years will I gather the Egyptians from the people whither they were scattered.'
options: forty
twenty
thirty
fifty
questions.correctAnswer: forty
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:13 says that at the end of forty years, God will gather the Egyptians from the people where they were scattered.

questions.question: What land will God give to Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon as his reward, according to Ezekiel 29:19?
options: The land of Egypt
The land of Israel
The land of Babylon
The land of Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:19 states that God will give the land of Egypt to Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon as his wages.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29:14, into which land will God cause the Egyptians to return after their captivity?
options: The land of Pathros
The land of Canaan
The land of Babylon
The land of Midian
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Pathros
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:14 says God will bring the Egyptians back into the land of Pathros, their habitation.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 29:15 says Egypt will exalt itself above the nations after their return.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:15 states Egypt shall be the basest of kingdoms and shall not exalt itself above the nations.

questions.question: What will Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon receive for his labor against Tyrus, according to Ezekiel 29:20?
options: The land of Egypt
Gold and silver
The city of Jerusalem
The land of Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: The land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:20 declares that God has given Nebuchadrezzar the land of Egypt for his labor.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29:21, what will God cause to bud forth in that day?
options: The horn of the house of Israel
The tree of life
The river of Babylon
The temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The horn of the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:21 says God will cause the horn of the house of Israel to bud forth.

questions.question: Where will the land of Egypt be made utterly waste and desolate according to Ezekiel 29:10?
options: From the tower of Syene to the border of Ethiopia
From Jerusalem to Babylon
From Egypt to Canaan
From the Red Sea to the Mediterranean Sea
questions.correctAnswer: From the tower of Syene to the border of Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:10 states that the land of Egypt will be made waste from the tower of Syene to the border of Ethiopia.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 29 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 29 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and self-reliance. Based on Ezekiel 29, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God?
options: God is against those who claim ownership and control apart from Him
Pride leads to immediate blessings and honor
Self-reliance is the key to spiritual success
We should always rely on our own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God is against those who claim ownership and control apart from Him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:3 and 29:9 show that God opposes Pharaoh's claim that the river is his own, demonstrating that trust and ownership belong to God alone.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 29 teach us about humility when facing trials or judgment?
options: We should accept God's discipline and recognize our weakness
We should blame others for our failures
Pride will protect us from hardship
Ignoring God’s warnings is wise
questions.correctAnswer: We should accept God's discipline and recognize our weakness
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 describe how Pharaoh and Egypt will be humbled and left desolate because of their arrogance and failure to support Israel, teaching humility in trials.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by hardship and loss. According to Ezekiel 29, what hope can you offer about restoration?
options: God promises to restore and gather His people after a time of discipline
Hardship is permanent and unchangeable
God abandons those who suffer
Restoration happens without any time of waiting
questions.correctAnswer: God promises to restore and gather His people after a time of discipline
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:13-14 shows God’s promise to gather the Egyptians after forty years of desolation, illustrating His faithfulness to restore those who repent.

questions.question: What biblical truth about God’s sovereignty over nations can we learn from Ezekiel 29?
options: God controls the rise and fall of kingdoms according to His purposes
Nations are independent of God's will
God always blesses the proud and powerful
Human plans are more important than God’s plans
questions.correctAnswer: God controls the rise and fall of kingdoms according to His purposes
questions.explanation: Verses 18-20 illustrate how God uses Nebuchadrezzar and Babylon as His instrument to punish Egypt, showing His sovereignty over nations.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 29 encourage believers to persevere through spiritual trials?
options: God’s discipline may be long but leads to ultimate restoration
Trials indicate God’s rejection
Perseverance is unnecessary because God never tests His people
Suffering should be avoided at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: God’s discipline may be long but leads to ultimate restoration
questions.explanation: The forty years of desolation (verses 11-12) emphasize that God’s timing in discipline is purposeful and leads to eventual restoration (verses 13-14).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to forget God during prosperity. What warning from Ezekiel 29 applies?
options: Claiming ownership and control apart from God brings judgment
Prosperity guarantees God’s favor
Self-sufficiency is a sign of spiritual maturity
Ignoring God is harmless
questions.correctAnswer: Claiming ownership and control apart from God brings judgment
questions.explanation: Pharaoh's prideful claim in verse 3, 'My river is mine own,' is condemned by God, warning against self-exaltation apart from Him.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 29 instruct believers to act regarding obedience and trust in God’s Word?
options: Obedience to God’s Word is essential even when it involves hardship
Disobedience will be overlooked if intentions are good
Trusting God is optional
God’s Word is only for certain people
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God’s Word is essential even when it involves hardship
questions.explanation: The prophecy against Egypt (verses 2 and 8) shows that disobedience leads to judgment, indicating the importance of obedience to God’s commands.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 29, Egypt will be inhabited and prosperous continuously for forty years.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:11 states the land of Egypt will be uninhabited for forty years, indicating a period of desolation.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 29 teaches that God’s judgment is final and leaves no hope for restoration.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:13-14 reveals that after the time of judgment, God will gather and restore Egypt, showing His mercy and hope for restoration.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I will bring again the captivity of Egypt, and will cause them to return into the land of __________."
options: Pathros
Babylon
Jerusalem
Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: Pathros
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:14 specifically mentions the land of Pathros as the place God will restore the Egyptians to after captivity.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 29 teach about humility in leadership and authority?
options: Leaders must recognize God's authority and not claim ownership as Pharaoh did
Leaders should assert their power above all
Authority is independent from God's will
Leaders are entitled to claim all resources for themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must recognize God's authority and not claim ownership as Pharaoh did
questions.explanation: The condemnation of Pharaoh in verse 3 for claiming the river as his own illustrates the need for leaders to submit to God’s authority.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29, what is a practical lesson about trusting in human allies or supports?
options: Human supports like Egypt can fail and cause harm
Human allies are always reliable
We should place ultimate trust in people rather than God
Relying on others guarantees success
questions.correctAnswer: Human supports like Egypt can fail and cause harm
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 describe Egypt as a 'staff of reed' that breaks when leaned upon, teaching that human help can be unreliable.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 29 teach about God’s justice and fairness in dealing with nations?
options: God rewards labor and punishes wrongdoing according to His purposes
God ignores the deeds of nations
God is partial to some nations without cause
Justice is irrelevant to God
questions.correctAnswer: God rewards labor and punishes wrongdoing according to His purposes
questions.explanation: Verses 18-20 show God rewarding Nebuchadrezzar for his service against Egypt, demonstrating divine justice and purpose.

questions.question: How can Ezekiel 29 guide believers in their attitude toward God’s timing in their lives?
options: God’s timing may include prolonged waiting but is purposeful and leads to blessing
God acts immediately in every situation
Waiting is a sign of God’s disfavor
One should not wait for God’s timing
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing may include prolonged waiting but is purposeful and leads to blessing
questions.explanation: The forty years of desolation followed by restoration (verses 11-14) illustrate God’s purposeful timing for discipline and blessing.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 29 teach about the importance of recognizing God as Lord in everyday life?
options: Acknowledging God’s Lordship leads to wisdom and humility
Ignoring God has no consequences
God’s Lordship is only for religious leaders
One can live successfully without God
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging God’s Lordship leads to wisdom and humility
questions.explanation: Verses 6, 9, and 16 emphasize that all will know God is the LORD through judgment and restoration, teaching the importance of recognizing His authority.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 29 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 29.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 29, Pharaoh is metaphorically described as which creature, symbolizing his dominion over Egypt's rivers?
options: A great dragon
A lion
A serpent
An eagle
questions.correctAnswer: A great dragon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:3 describes Pharaoh as 'the great dragon that lieth in the midst of his rivers,' highlighting his pride and control over the Nile and Egypt.

questions.question: What does God say He will use to pull Pharaoh out of his rivers in Ezekiel 29?
options: Hooks in his jaws
Chains of iron
Winds of destruction
A mighty flood
questions.correctAnswer: Hooks in his jaws
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:4 states God will put hooks in Pharaoh's jaws and bring him up out of the rivers, symbolizing captivity and humiliation.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29, how long will the land of Egypt be desolate and uninhabited?
options: Forty years
Seventy years
Seven years
One hundred years
questions.correctAnswer: Forty years
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:11 specifies that no foot of man or beast shall pass through Egypt, nor shall it be inhabited for forty years, indicating a divinely appointed period of desolation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'staff of reed' mentioned in Ezekiel 29:6 in relation to Egypt's support of Israel?
options: It symbolizes Egypt’s weakness and unreliability as support
It represents Egypt's strength and protection
It is a symbol of God’s covenant with Egypt
It refers to Egyptian agricultural tools
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Egypt’s weakness and unreliability as support
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:6 likens Egypt to a 'staff of reed' which breaks when leaned upon, emphasizing Egypt’s failure as a dependable ally to Israel.

questions.question: Which king is prophesied to gain the land of Egypt as wages for his service against Tyre?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
Cyrus king of Persia
Pharaoh king of Egypt
Darius king of Persia
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:19 states God will give Egypt to Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon as payment for his army’s service against Tyre.

questions.question: How is the future status of Egypt described after the forty years of desolation?
options: A base kingdom that will not exalt itself above nations
A mighty empire restored to former glory
A land merged with Babylon
A place of exile for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A base kingdom that will not exalt itself above nations
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:14-15 predicts Egypt will be restored but as "the basest of the kingdoms" and will no longer dominate other nations.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Ezekiel 29:9 for God's judgment on Egypt?
options: Because Egypt claimed the river as their own and said 'The river is mine'
Because Egypt allied with Babylon
Because Egypt worshipped foreign gods
Because Egypt oppressed the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: Because Egypt claimed the river as their own and said 'The river is mine'
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:9 highlights God's anger because Pharaoh arrogantly claimed ownership over the Nile, declaring 'The river is mine, and I have made it.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'I will scatter the Egyptians among the nations, and will _______ them through the countries.'
options: disperse
conquer
enslave
protect
questions.correctAnswer: disperse
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:12 states God will scatter and disperse the Egyptians among the nations as part of His judgment.

questions.question: What is the literary significance of the repeated phrase 'they shall know that I am the LORD' in Ezekiel 29?
options: It emphasizes God’s sovereignty and the purpose of judgment
It signals a new covenant with Egypt
It is a call to worship the Egyptian gods
It marks the end of Israel’s exile
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God’s sovereignty and the purpose of judgment
questions.explanation: The phrase appears multiple times (e.g., 29:6, 29:9, 29:16) to affirm that God’s actions are ultimately to demonstrate His lordship over nations.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 29 prophesies that Israel will remain dependent on Egypt as a source of confidence after Egypt's downfall.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:16 declares Egypt will no longer be the confidence of Israel, signaling a break from reliance on Egypt.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'the horn of the house of Israel' in Ezekiel 29:21?
options: It symbolizes the strength and future rise of Israel
It refers to an actual horn used in worship
It denotes the destruction of Israel
It represents the Babylonian king’s power
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the strength and future rise of Israel
questions.explanation: The 'horn' is a common biblical metaphor for power and strength; here it signifies Israel's future restoration and glory.

questions.question: Ezekiel 29:7 uses imagery describing Egypt breaking Israel’s shoulders and loins. What does this metaphor imply about Egypt’s relationship with Israel?
options: Egypt’s support was harmful and destructive
Egypt provided strong and lasting support
Israel oppressed Egypt
They shared a peaceful alliance
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt’s support was harmful and destructive
questions.explanation: The imagery of broken shoulders and loins (Ezekiel 29:7) illustrates Egypt’s failure as a reliable support, causing Israel injury instead.

questions.question: Which geographical boundaries does Ezekiel 29:10 mention as the extent of God's judgment upon Egypt?
options: From the tower of Syene to the border of Ethiopia
From the Nile delta to the Red Sea
From Memphis to Thebes
From Jerusalem to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: From the tower of Syene to the border of Ethiopia
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:10 specifies these boundaries to emphasize the totality of Egypt’s desolation.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And all the inhabitants of Egypt shall know that I am the LORD, because they have been a ______ of reed to the house of Israel.'
options: staff
shield
wall
tower
questions.correctAnswer: staff
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:6 uses the metaphor of a 'staff of reed' to describe Egypt’s fragility and unreliability as support for Israel.

questions.question: What historical context does Ezekiel 29:18 provide about Nebuchadrezzar’s army and their campaign against Tyre?
options: They served a great service but received no wages
They conquered Tyre quickly and gained much spoil
They allied with Egypt against Tyre
They failed to attack Tyre at all
questions.correctAnswer: They served a great service but received no wages
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:18 describes Nebuchadrezzar’s army suffering greatly in the siege of Tyre, yet receiving no reward, setting the stage for Egypt as their payment.

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 29 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 29 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 29, how does God describe Pharaoh, king of Egypt?
options: The great dragon that lieth in the midst of his rivers
A mighty lion ruling the desert
A shepherd leading his flock
A wise eagle soaring above the nations
questions.correctAnswer: The great dragon that lieth in the midst of his rivers
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:3 portrays Pharaoh as 'the great dragon that lieth in the midst of his rivers,' illustrating his arrogance and self-sufficiency. This imagery aligns with other biblical symbolism of evil rulers as dragons (e.g., Revelation 12:9, Isaiah 27:1), emphasizing God's sovereignty over proud powers.

questions.question: What reason does God give for bringing judgment upon Egypt in Ezekiel 29?
options: Because they claimed, 'The river is mine, and I have made it.'
Because they worshipped idols of gold and silver.
Because they oppressed the children of Israel with harsh labor.
Because they refused to offer sacrifices to the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: Because they claimed, 'The river is mine, and I have made it.'
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:9 reveals that Egypt's arrogance in claiming ownership and control over the river (Nile) prompted God's judgment. This reflects the biblical theme of God's authority over creation (Psalm 24:1, Isaiah 40:12) and the folly of human pride (Proverbs 16:18).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 29, what will happen to Egypt for forty years?
options: It shall be desolate and uninhabited.
It shall prosper and become a great kingdom.
It shall be destroyed by fire.
It shall be redeemed and restored immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be desolate and uninhabited.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:11 states Egypt will be desolate and uninhabited for forty years, symbolizing divine judgment and exile, similar to other periods of punishment in biblical history (e.g., Israel's Babylonian exile in Jeremiah 25:11). This reflects God's justice and control over nations.

questions.question: What does God promise to do at the end of the forty years of desolation for Egypt?
options: Gather the Egyptians from the nations where they were scattered.
Destroy Egypt permanently.
Make Egypt the greatest nation again.
Send them into perpetual exile without return.
questions.correctAnswer: Gather the Egyptians from the nations where they were scattered.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:13 assures restoration after judgment, as God promises to regather the Egyptians, a theme consistent with God's covenant faithfulness and restoration promises seen in Israel's history (Deuteronomy 30:3, Isaiah 11:11).

questions.question: What status will Egypt have after being restored according to Ezekiel 29?
options: It shall be the basest of the kingdoms, not exalted above nations.
It shall reign supreme over all nations.
It shall become a holy nation.
It shall be destroyed again immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be the basest of the kingdoms, not exalted above nations.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:15 predicts Egypt will be humbled and diminished in power after restoration, emphasizing God's sovereignty and the principle that nations must submit to Him (Daniel 4:17; Psalm 75:7). This humility aligns with biblical themes of God's judgment and mercy.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 29, why were the Egyptians considered a 'staff of reed' to Israel?
options: Because they broke and wounded Israel when leaned upon.
Because they provided strong support and protection.
Because they were a wise counsel to Israel.
Because they were a symbol of God's blessing.
questions.correctAnswer: Because they broke and wounded Israel when leaned upon.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:6-7 describes Egypt as a fragile support that caused injury to Israel, symbolizing unreliable alliances and the consequences of misplaced trust. This theme corresponds to biblical warnings against trusting in human strength over God (Psalm 20:7).

questions.question: What will happen to Pharaoh and the fish of his rivers according to Ezekiel 29?
options: They will be pulled out of the rivers and left in the wilderness.
They will flourish and multiply in the land.
They will be protected and blessed by God.
They will be gathered into a great city.
questions.correctAnswer: They will be pulled out of the rivers and left in the wilderness.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:4-5 describes God removing Pharaoh and the fish from the rivers and leaving them in the wilderness, symbolizing judgment and desolation. This reflects God's power over nature and nations (Job 12:10) and His judgment on pride.

questions.question: Who will receive Egypt as a reward for their service against Tyre, as stated in Ezekiel 29?
options: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
Pharaoh king of Egypt
The house of Israel
The king of Ethiopia
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:19-20 states God will give Egypt to Nebuchadrezzar as wages for his labor against Tyre, illustrating God's use of nations to accomplish His purposes, similar to His sovereign use of Babylon in Isaiah 10:5-6.

questions.question: What is the significance of God putting 'hooks in the jaws' of Pharaoh in Ezekiel 29?
options: Symbolizes God’s power to capture and control Egypt.
Symbolizes Pharaoh’s strength and independence.
Represents Egypt’s prosperity and growth.
Indicates an alliance between Egypt and Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: Symbolizes God’s power to capture and control Egypt.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:4 uses the imagery of hooks in jaws as a metaphor for God's sovereign control and judgment over Egypt, showing that even mighty powers are subject to His will (Psalm 2:4-6; Isaiah 45:1).

questions.question: What does God declare about Egypt’s rivers in Ezekiel 29?
options: He is against Pharaoh and his rivers and will make the land desolate.
They will overflow and bring abundant harvest.
They are sacred and protected by God.
They will be a source of healing for the nations.
questions.correctAnswer: He is against Pharaoh and his rivers and will make the land desolate.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:10 emphasizes God's judgment on Egypt’s rivers, which were life sources, indicating that even nature is subject to Divine judgment when associated with human pride, consistent with God's control over creation (Genesis 1:9-10).

questions.question: What will the house of Israel know after Egypt is no longer their confidence, according to Ezekiel 29?
options: They shall know that I am the Lord GOD.
They will seek alliances with other nations.
They will mourn their losses forever.
They shall become like Egypt in pride.
questions.correctAnswer: They shall know that I am the Lord GOD.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:16 teaches that Israel’s reliance on Egypt’s strength was sinful, and when that confidence fails, they will recognize God’s sovereignty, aligning with biblical calls to trust God alone (Psalm 20:7; Jeremiah 17:5-8).

questions.question: What does God promise to cause to bud forth from the house of Israel 'in that day' in Ezekiel 29?
options: The horn of the house of Israel
The fruit of the olive tree
The wings of the eagle
The roots of the cedar
questions.correctAnswer: The horn of the house of Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:21 mentions God causing the horn of Israel to bud, a messianic symbol of strength, victory, and kingship (1 Samuel 2:10; Psalm 18:2; Luke 1:69), pointing to God’s future restoration and empowerment of His people.

questions.question: What will happen to the cities of Egypt during the forty years of desolation according to Ezekiel 29?
options: They will be desolate among cities that are laid waste.
They will be fortified and protected.
They will be rebuilt and prosper.
They will be inhabited by Israelites.
questions.correctAnswer: They will be desolate among cities that are laid waste.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:12 declares that Egypt’s cities will be desolate like other ruined cities during the judgment period, reflecting the consequences of sin and God's justice (Jeremiah 25:10; Lamentations 5:17).

questions.question: What was the outcome for Nebuchadrezzar’s army after serving against Tyre as described in Ezekiel 29?
options: They had no wages or spoils for their service against Tyre.
They were richly rewarded with gold and silver.
They were given land in Egypt to settle.
They returned victorious with great plunder.
questions.correctAnswer: They had no wages or spoils for their service against Tyre.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:18 describes Nebuchadrezzar’s army serving against Tyre without pay, highlighting the harsh realities of military campaigns and God's sovereign provision by later granting Egypt as payment (Isaiah 14:24).

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 29 reveal about God's justice toward both man and beast in Egypt’s land?
options: God will cut off man and beast from the land.
God will protect the beasts but punish the man.
God will leave both man and beast unharmed.
God will bless the land with peace and prosperity.
questions.correctAnswer: God will cut off man and beast from the land.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 29:8 states God will bring a sword upon Egypt, cutting off both man and beast, demonstrating God's comprehensive judgment on sin affecting all creation (Genesis 6:7; Romans 8:22).
